ygData.subject: RE: [Re: Market in EQ]
ygData.msgSnippet: Well, how ever logical or nice this idea sounds, it s the LAST thing I want them coding on (well, perm death is the last thing I want them coding on actually).
ygData.messageBody:
Well, how ever logical or nice this idea sounds, it's the LAST thing I want
them coding on (well, perm death is the last thing I want them coding on
actually). There are SOOOOOO many other things in the game that need either
fixing or implimented that this conversation, I think, seems like a waste of
time. Plus, most of us don't want it anyways (me included). If I wanted
reality, I'd go hunting or fishing on the weekend.

-Zantaer/Leod, Fennin Ro

-----Original Message-----
From: Paul Heenan [mailto:pheenan@...]
Sent: Thursday, July 15, 1999 10:03 AM
To: 'EQ_Blacksmiths@onelist.com'
Subject: RE: [Re: [EQ_Blacksmiths] Market in EQ]


From: Paul Heenan <pheenan@...>

Everybody keeps missing the fact that Artifacts of Great power would
probably not deteriorate. Or anything that is magic for that matter, because
it has a special quality unlike normal items. But how about that Rusty
Longsword that you've been using for the last 6 months of adventuring. It
just doesn't make sense that that item would last too long. That's why it's
rusty.

My second point is that this could allow a lower level character to gain
specific items that weren't available before. Let's say as an item
deteriorates that it's AC and price do as well. Now, after a little wear,
that nifty Banded Tunic is now AC 7, and can be sold for 8-10pp. The
purchaser now takes it to a Smith and gets the item reapired for say 3-5pp
(which takes the item back to it's AC 15 state). Or, he/she can choose to
repair it over time, to save money. So now you have a set of armor that cost
fractionally less, but over time will yield the same protection as a full
suit of "fresh" armor.

Also, deterioration should not destroy the item completely. It should just
take it down to the lowest AC possible. Instead of losing those Banded
Bracers, just make them drop until AC is 1 or 2. Then you have to go get
them polished to restore their protective value.

Just my thoughts :)

Xyler, Tunare's humble servant
Ranger of the 17th Season
Master Smith

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Nick Emmerich [SMTP:seorin@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, July 14, 1999 10:02 PM
> To: EQ_Blacksmiths@onelist.com
> Subject: Re: [Re: [EQ_Blacksmiths] Market in EQ]

> From: Nick Emmerich <seorin@...>
>
> ok, I'm Rennin with the big mouth, I have to put my 2 cents into the next
> major discussion on this list, so here goes nothing:
>
> While I must say deteriorating armor would be EXCELLENT revenue for
> smiths, I am 100% against it. It's one of those things you have to
> experience before you can really say what you want. Go play Diablo and see
> how much you like armor deterioration then :) That's a simple annoyance,
> though. The main point of this letter is that I'm very very against armor
> deterioration. I will write a short anecdote below for those who wish to
> read it, but if you're short on time, don't bother. It's just a relation
> of one of my experiences that's a part
> of my anti-deterioration attitude. If you've got the time, read on :)
>
> I used to play Sierra's The Realm. I played that damn game from right
> after beta (v 2.xx). It was a pretty good game until the release of 3.xx.
> That's when they implemented armor deterioration..... Well, to briefly
> explain items in the game, you had an item that was mundane. Enchanters
> could cast several different enchantments on the thing to make it better.
> Every time, though, there was a chance it would destroy the item, and the
> more enchanted it was, the higher that chance was. 6 enchantments were
> unheard of, 5 were rare, and 4 were
> there, but difficult. I had just replaced my 4 permed (permanents, or
> enchantments) adamantium tunic with a 5 permed magical armor. I can't
> remember the name, but it was naturally black (another game feature was
> you could dye your clothing. Adamantium came light blue, the armor I got
> was rare and came black like I like it =P). This armor was pretty much the
> best you could get. I also had a sword of similar quality with 4 perms on
> it. In one fight (it was a very very long fight with the toughest humanoid
> NPC in the game at the time - I
> can't remember the name, but it was human and wore adamantium. Was a
> champion of light or some crap like that - I had to kill it =P), I lost
> both the tunic and the sword in that fight. After he destroyed my
> priceless tunic (literally, it was truly one-of-a-kind), and my
> near-priceless sword, I ran from the fight. I ran, logged out, and never
> logged back in. Losing items that take that much work to get in one fight
> was too much... I haven't even tried logging in since. My account has
> since expired.
>
> I don't want this to happen to EQ... to get that rare piece of armor and
> just lose it in one shot like that... no, that's just too terrible a thing
> to introduce into a game. I don't want to see deteriorating armor at
> all... it's got too much potential to really cause a lot of frustration.
> -Rennin of E'Ci
> Trade Council GM
>
> Jason Coan wrote:
>
> > From: "Jason Coan" <COANJ@...>
> >
> > OK, simple question, how many of you people that are for items
> deteriorating and going poof have any magic plate? (none I'd bet)
> >
> > I've spent about 2 months to get the armor that I am now wearing, I'd be
> pissed to an extreem if I were in the middle of a fight and I see a
> message "Your Charred Black Tunic has fallen appart". That one piece of
> armor alone took me the better part of week to get.
> >
> > Ok, so you say I should have to get it repaired by a smith. I am DE,
> and by choice I have lowered my faction to the point where I will never be
> able to go into Freeport or Rivervale, and due to built in factions, I can
> not go to any other elf city nor can I go into gnome, dwarf, or barbarian
> city. Which means that I would have to search, not only for a respectable
> smith that I trusted, but also an evil one, or trek my self across the
> world to Qeynos. Simply to get my armor "repaired". Now if that isn't
> bad enough.....
> >
> > Often my group will go deep into a dungeon, deep to the point where
> either a caster has to group gate us to get us out, or we have to spend
> 30-45 min fighting out way out of the dungeon. And quite often we'll all
> camp and logout in a "safe" spot in the dungeon, so sometimes we will be
> in a dungeon litterly for days. Now, say I get the message "your rubicite
> helm is begining to weaken, you should take it for repairs soon", that
> means that my entire group would have to leave the dungeon so that I might
> quest to get my armor repaired.
> >
> > I find neither to be acceptable. What I do find about this, is that
> there are some smiths who think they don't make enough money, so they want
> armor to wear out, so it has to either be replaced or repaired (more money
> for smiths). What they fail to concider is the fact that you will not
> always be wearing banded armor.
> >
> > >>> Peter Wong <lkworthpete@...> 7.14.99 9:19:45 AM >>>
> > From: Peter Wong <lkworthpete@...>
> >
> > XxKommiexX@... wrote:
> > From: XxKommiexX@...
> >
> > It would make people too mad. Having a nice piece of magic armor that
> took
> > forever to get disappear because it wore out. I don't like this idea, as
> it
> > would just make EQ more like Diablo and Ultima Online, which I hope they
> > would want to try and stay away from.
> >
> > ------------------------------------------
> >
> > Some other RPG's I've played made it so that common wear items wore
> quicker
> > than others as well as making rare quest items not wear very little or
> not at
> > all since they are supposed to be considered priceless. I think the
> idea of
> > making items wear would be a great thing for the trade. A shield and
> sword
> > would wear quicker than say boots or leggings. This gives smiths an
> > oppurtunity to increase their skills with less cost if they want to work
> on
> > repairing and improving items.
> >
